Text: In the realm of molecular biology, DNA polymerase plays a pivotal role in the replication process. This enzyme, a key player in the life cycle of all organisms, traverses the double helix, unwinding it while simultaneously synthesizing new strands. It reads the template strand, forming a new complementary strand, akin to typing from a book while writing a mirror copy. This intricate dance of synthesis ensures the faithful transmission of genetic information from one generation to the next. DNA polymerase, in essence, is the librarian of life, meticulously maintaining the archive of genetic codes that govern all living organisms.

Secondary structure elements of many protein families exhibit differential conservation on their opposing faces. Amphipathic helices and beta-sheets by definition possess this property, and play crucial functional roles. This type of evolutionary trajectory of a protein family is usually critical to the functions of the protein family, as well as in creating functions within subfamilies. That is, differential conservation maintains properties of a protein structure related to its orientation, and that are important in packing, recognition, and catalysis. Here I define and formulate a new concept, called the selection moment, that detects this evolutionary process in protein sequences. A treatment of its various applications is detailed.

In the intricate dance of life, photosynthesis plays a pivotal role. This biochemical process, carried out by plants, algae, and certain bacteria, converts light energy, usually from the sun, into chemical energy. It involves the green pigment chlorophyll, which absorbs light, and carbon dioxide, water, and minerals from the soil. The conversion process results in the creation of glucose, a simple sugar for energy, and oxygen, a vital component for respiration in most life forms. This symbiotic relationship between plants and the atmosphere is a testament to the harmony that underpins our ecosystem.

Both short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) and microRNAs (miRNAs) mediate the repression of specific sequences of mRNA through the RNA interference pathway. In the last years several experiments have supported the hypothesis that siRNAs and miRNAs may be functionally interchangeable, at least in cultured cells. In this work we verify that this hypothesis is also supported by a computational evidence. We show that a method specifically trained to predict the activity of the exogenous siRNAs assigns a high silencing level to experimentally determined human miRNAs. This result not only supports the idea of siRNAs and miRNAs equivalence but indicates that it is possible to use computational tools developed using synthetic small interference RNAs to investigate endogenous miRNAs.

In the realm of genetics, the CRISPR-Cas9 system has revolutionized molecular biology. This revolutionary tool allows for precise editing of DNA sequences, opening doors to potential therapeutic applications and genetic engineering. By exploiting the adaptive immune system of bacteria, scientists can now cut, copy, and paste segments of DNA with unprecedented accuracy. This technology holds immense promise for combating genetic diseases, improving crop yields, and even modifying the traits of organisms. However, as with any powerful technology, the ethical implications must be carefully considered, ensuring responsible and safe use for the betterment of humanity.

We study general aspects of active motion with fluctuations in the speed and the direction of motion in two dimensions. We consider the case in which fluctuations in the speed are not correlated to fluctuations in the direction of motion, and assume that both processes can be described by independent characteristic time-scales. We show the occurrence of a complex transient that can exhibit a series of alternating regimes of motion, for two different angular dynamics which correspond to persistent and directed random walks. We also show additive corrections to the diffusion coefficient. The characteristic time-scales are also exposed in the velocity autocorrelation, which is a sum of exponential forms.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a significant player. Epigenetics, a layer above DNA sequencing, determines the functional activity of genes without altering the underlying DNA code. It's a complex dance of proteins and chemical tags that control gene expression, influenced by various factors such as age, environment, lifestyle, and disease states. Epigenetic changes can be reversible, offering potential for therapeutic interventions, especially in conditions linked to aberrant gene expression, like cancer. This fascinating field bridges the gap between nature and nurture, underscoring the dynamic interplay between our genetic inheritance and the external influences that shape our health and development.

We study the length distribution of a particular class of DNA sequences known as 5'UTR exons. These exons belong to the messanger RNA of protein coding genes, but they are not coding (they are located upstream of the coding portion of the mRNA) and are thus less constrained from an evolutionary point of view. We show that both in mouse and in human these exons show a very clean power law decay in their length distribution and suggest a simple evolutionary model which may explain this finding. We conjecture that this power law behaviour could indeed be a general feature of higher eukaryotes.

Delving into the intricate world of genetics, we find the fascinating realm of DNA methylation. This process, a crucial epigenetic modification, serves as a molecular switch, regulating gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. Methyl groups, small molecules derived from dietary sources, are added to the DNA structure, thus changing its accessibility to transcription factors, and ultimately determining which genes are active or silenced. DNA methylation plays a pivotal role in various biological processes, including cellular differentiation, embryonic development, and tumor suppression, offering profound insights into the complexities of life at its most fundamental level.

We used the atomic force microscope to manipulate and unfold individual molecules of the titin I27 domain and reconstructed its free energy surface using Jarzynski's equality. The free energy surface for both stretching and unfolding was reconstructed using an exact formula that relates the nonequilibrium work fluctuations to the molecular free energy. In addition, the unfolding free energy barrier, i.e. the activation energy, was directly obtained from experimental data for the first time. This work demonstrates that Jarzynski's equality can be used to analyze nonequilibrium single-molecule experiments, and to obtain the free energy surfaces for molecular systems, including interactions for which only nonequilibrium work can be measured.

In the intricate dance of life, the process of photosynthesis stands as a testament to nature's efficiency. Plants, algae, and some bacteria harness solar energy, converting carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen. This biochemical marvel unfolds in chloroplasts, the green powerhouses within plant cells. During daylight hours, these organelles absorb sunlight, splitting water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen. The oxygen is released as a byproduct, while the hydrogen is combined with carbon dioxide, sourced from the air or the plant itself, to create glucose. This vital energy source fuels the plant's growth, while the oxygen enriches our atmosphere, sustaining life on Earth. Photosynthesis, therefore, is not just a biological phenomenon. it's a lifeline that binds all living things in a shared, sun-kissed symphony of survival.

The maintainance of a stable periodicity during the yeast metabolic cycle involving approximately half of the genome requires a very strict and efficient control of gene expression. For this reason, the metabolic cycle is a very good candidate for testing the role of a class of post-transcriptional regulators, the so called PUF-family, whose genome-wide mRNA binding specificity was recently experimentally assessed. Here we show that an integrated computational analysis of gene expression time series during the metabolic cycle and the mRNA binding specificity of PUF-family proteins allow for a clear demonstration of the very specific role exerted by selective post-transcriptional mRNA degradation in yeast metabolic cycle global regulation.

In the realm of cellular biology, mitochondria, often dubbed as the powerhouses of the cell, are integral to life. They are membrane-bound organelles responsible for generating adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy currency of cells, through a process called cellular respiration. Mitochondria also play a crucial role in programmed cell death, a mechanism that ensures the body can regulate cell growth and prevent uncontrolled proliferation. Interestingly, mitochondria have their own DNA, distinct from the nuclear DNA, which carries genes essential for their structure and function. This double membrane-enclosed organelle, with its intricate biological functions, is a testament to the complex and interconnected nature of cellular life.

Chemical reaction systems with a low to moderate number of molecules are typically modeled as discrete jump Markov processes. These systems are oftentimes simulated with methods that produce statistically exact sample paths such as the Gillespie Algorithm or the Next Reaction Method. In this paper we make explicit use of the fact that the initiation times of the reactions can be represented as the firing times of independent, unit rate Poisson processes with internal times given by integrated propensity functions. Using this representation we derive a modified Next Reaction Method and, in a way that achieves efficiency over existing approaches for exact simulation, extend it to systems with time dependent propensities as well as to systems with delays.

In the intricate tapestry of life, symbiosis emerges as a profound testament to evolution's adaptive genius. This mutualistic relationship, where two different species live in close proximity, often to the advantage of both, is a biological phenomenon of great significance. Consider the relationship between corals and zooxanthellae, single-celled algae residing within coral tissues. Through photosynthesis, these algae provide the coral with essential nutrients, while the coral offers the algae a protected environment and access to sunlight. This symbiotic alliance not only ensures the survival of both species but also contributes significantly to the health and diversity of marine ecosystems, serving as a vibrant example of the harmonious interplay between life forms.

This paper describes a design of a molecular propagation system in molecular communication. Molecular communication is a new communication paradigm where biological and artificially-created nanomachines communicate over a short distance using molecules. A molecular propagation system in molecular communication directionally transports molecules from a sender to a receiver. In the design described in this paper, protein filaments glide over immobilized motor proteins along preconfigured microlithographic tracks, and the gliding protein filaments carry and transport molecules from a sender to a receiver. In the design, DNA hybridization is used to load and unload the molecules onto and from the carriers at a sender and a receiver. In the design, loading/transporting/unloading processes are autonomous and require no external control.

In the intricate world of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges, a field that delves into the structural changes in gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetic modifications, such as methylation and acetylation, influence gene activity and can be affected by various factors like age, environment, and lifestyle choices. These modifications play a vital role in cellular processes, from development and growth to disease prevention and treatment. Epigenetic studies are revolutionizing our understanding of hereditary traits, potentially offering new avenues for disease management and personalized medicine.

Schizophrenia is a severe, currently incurable, relatively common mental condition. Its symptoms are complex and widespread. It structurally and functionally affects cortical and subcortical regions involved in cognitive, emotional and motivational aspects of behavior. Its cause is unknown, its diagnosis is based on statistical behavior and its treatment is elusive.   Our paradigm addresses the complexity of schizophrenic symptoms. Building upon recent neural vulnerability and limbic dysregulation hypotheses, it offers a mathematical model for the evolution of the limbic system under perturbation. Dependence on parameters and the concept of "bifurcation" could be the key to understanding the threshold between "normality" and "disease".

In botany, the process of photosynthesis is a marvel of nature, a symphony of life's building blocks. Under the sun's radiant glow, chlorophyll, the green pigment in plant cells, absorbs light energy. This energy is harnessed to split water molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. Simultaneously, carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is absorbed and incorporated into glucose, a simple sugar, via the Calvin cycle. This process, essential for life on Earth, not only sustains the plant but also provides oxygen for all aerobic organisms and serves as the primary food source for heterotrophic life forms. Thus, photosynthesis is an intricate dance of elements, an unyielding engine of life that underpins the health of our planet.

An analytical description of the response properties of simple but realistic neuron models in the presence of noise is still lacking. We determine completely up to the second order the firing statistics of a single and a pair of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons (LIFs) receiving some common slowly filtered white noise. In particular, the auto- and cross-correlation functions of the output spike trains of pairs of cells are obtained from an improvement of the adiabatic approximation introduced in Mor+04. These two functions define the firing variability and firing synchronization between neurons, and are of much importance for understanding neuron communication.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis stands as a pivotal process, a symphony of chemistry orchestrated by plants and photosynthetic organisms. This miracle of nature converts sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into glucose, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This process not only fuels the organisms themselves but also sustains the atmosphere, providing the essential oxygen that animals, including humans, require for respiration. Photosynthesis, therefore, is a vital link in the web of life, underpinning the very existence of countless species on our planet.

A description for regulatory genetic network based on generalized potential energy is constructed. The potential energy is derived from the steady state solution of linearized Fokker-Plank equation, and the result is shown to be equivalent to the system of coupled oscillators. The correspondence between the quantities from the mechanical picture and the steady-state fluctuations is established. Explicit calculation is given for auto-regulatory networks in which, the force constant associated with the degree of protein is very weak. Negative feedback not only suppresses the fluctuations but also increases the steepness of the potential. The results for the fluctuations agree completely with those obtained from linear noise Fokker-Planck equation.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis plays a pivotal role, a symphony of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and light. This process, performed by green plants, algae, and some bacteria, transforms sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into glucose, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This oxygen sustains countless organisms, while glucose serves as a vital energy source. Photosynthesis's efficiency is crucial to maintaining the balance of Earth's atmosphere, ensuring the survival of diverse life forms and the planet's biosphere. This biological marvel, through its intricate mechanisms, underpins the very foundations of life on Earth.

We show how accurate kinetic information, such as the rates of protein folding and unfolding, can be extracted from replica-exchange molecular dynamics (REMD) simulations. From the brief and continuous trajectory segments between replica exchanges, we estimate short-time propagators in conformation space and use them to construct a master equation. For a helical peptide in explicit water, we determine the rates of transitions both locally between microscopic conformational states and globally for folding and unfolding. We show that accurate rates in the ~1/(100 ns) to ~1/(1 ns) range can be obtained from REMD with exchange times of 5 ps, in excellent agreement with results from long equilibrium molecular dynamics.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent deep-sea anglerfish is a captivating spectacle. This enigmatic creature, adapted to the dark abyss, emits a eerie glow produced by a light-producing organ called photophore. The anglerfish's dorsal fin sports a luminescent lure, which it uses to attract unsuspecting prey towards its gaping mouth. The anglerfish's unique lifestyle, characterized by extreme pressure, scant food, and a life-altering mating ritual, exemplifies the remarkable adaptations found in deep-sea organisms. Despite its ominous appearance, the anglerfish serves as a symbol of resilience and survival in one of Earth's most inhospitable environments.

The development of a large non-coding fraction in eukaryotic DNA and the phenomenon of the code-bloat in the field of evolutionary computations show a striking similarity. This seems to suggest that (in the presence of mechanisms of code growth) the evolution of a complex code can't be attained without maintaining a large inactive fraction. To test this hypothesis we performed computer simulations of an evolutionary toy model for Turing machines, studying the relations among fitness and coding/non-coding ratio while varying mutation and code growth rates. The results suggest that, in our model, having a large reservoir of non-coding states constitutes a great (long term) evolutionary advantage.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA, the hereditary molecule, assumes a pivotal role. It's a double helix, a twisted ladder of nucleotides, each bearing a phosphate-sugar backbone and a nitrogenous base. Adenine pairs with thymine, while cytosine links with guanine, maintaining the ladder's integrity. This genetic code, encoded within DNA, is translated into proteins by messenger RNA, which serves as an intermediary. These proteins, the workhorses of the cell, carry out the myriad functions essential for life, from enzymatic catalysis to structural support. Thus, DNA and proteins form a symbiotic dance, the very essence of life's intricate choreography.

Population stratification is a problem encountered in several areas of biology and public health. We tackle this problem by mapping a population and its elements attributes into a hypergraph, a natural extension of the concept of graph or network to encode associations among any number of elements. On this hypergraph, we construct a statistical model reflecting our intuition about how the elements attributes can emerge from a postulated population structure. Finally, we introduce the concept of stratification representativeness as a mean to identify the simplest stratification already containing most of the information about the population structure. We demonstrate the power of this framework stratifying an animal and a human population based on phenotypic and genotypic properties, respectively.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, or firefly squid, is a captivating creature. Found in the deep ocean's twilight zone, these squid emit a soft, blue-green glow, a result of a chemical reaction in a light-producing organ called the photophore. This natural lantern serves multiple purposes, from camouflage during predator attacks to communication and mate attraction. The bioluminescent squid's unique traits offer researchers valuable insights into the mysteries of life in the deep sea, shedding light on the evolutionary adaptations necessary for survival in the dark abyss.

Developing fast and efficient algorithms for retrieval of objects to a given user query is an area of active research. The present study investigates retrieval of time series objects from a phoneme database to a given user pattern or query. The proposed method maps the one-dimensional time series retrieval into a sequence retrieval problem by partitioning the multi-dimensional phase-space using k-means clustering. The problem of whole sequence as well as subsequence matching is considered. Robustness of the proposed technique is investigated on phoneme time series corrupted with additive white Gaussian noise. The shortcoming of classical power-spectral techniques for time series retrieval is also discussed.

In the realm of genetics, a remarkable discovery unfolded: CRISPR-Cas9. This revolutionary tool is a gene-editing system, allowing scientists to precisely alter DNA sequences. It's akin to a molecular scissors, snipping specific genes and replacing them with desired alterations. This technology holds immense potential, from correcting genetic diseases to enhancing crops for food security. It's a leap forward in our understanding and manipulation of life's blueprint, promising a future where we can eradicate disease, improve agriculture, and even tackle climate change at its roots. Yet, the ethical implications are profound, as the power to rewrite life's code raises questions about the boundaries of human intervention and the potential consequences for future generations. The age of gene editing is here, ushering in a new era of scientific exploration and ethical debate.

The peculiarity of the distribution and geometry of metallic ions in enzymes pushed us to set the hypothesis that metallic ions in active-site act like tiny antennas able to pick up very feeble e.m. signals. Enzymatic activity of Cu2+, Zn2+ Superoxide Dismutase (SOD1) and Fe2+ Xanthine Oxidase (XO) has been studied, following in vitro generation and removal of free radicals. We observed that Superoxide radicals generation by XO is increased by a weak field having the Larmor frequency fL of Fe2+ while the SOD1 kinetics is sensibly reduced by exposure to a weak field having the frequency fL of Cu2+ ion.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis, a fundamental process carried out by plants, algae, and some bacteria, plays a pivotal role. This biochemical reaction harnesses sunlight's energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen, effectively sustaining life on Earth. The green pigment chlorophyll, found in chloroplasts, acts as a solar panel, absorbing light and powering the transformation of carbon dioxide into glucose. This process not only fuels the organisms themselves but also releases oxygen into the atmosphere, a vital component for most aerobic life forms. Thus, photosynthesis, in its simplicity, encapsulates the interconnectedness and harmony of life on our planet.

The understanding of inactivation radiobiological mechanism in individual cells is important when from one side the application of ionizing radiation to tumour therapy and from the other side the protection against radiation are to be effectively improved. Important part of this mechanism is double-strand break (DSB) formation. these DSB may be formed directly by impacting ionizing particles or indirectly by different secondary radicals. The latter kind of formation is much more frequent when cells contain normal water content. Mathematical model of the corresponding chemical stage will be presented with the aim to demonstrate how the individual radicals, but also other chemical agents present in the water during irradiation may influence DSB formation.

In the intricate world of genetics, a single nucleotide polymorphism, or SNP, can significantly impact an organism's traits. These minor changes in DNA sequence, often occurring at gene boundaries, can lead to a variety of effects, from subtle differences in eye color to more profound alterations in disease susceptibility. SNPs are crucial in understanding genetic diversity, evolution, and the mapping of genes responsible for hereditary diseases. Though individual SNPs may appear insignificant, their collective impact on genetic expression can shape the course of life at the molecular level. This knowledge can open doors to targeted therapies and personalized medicine, paving the way for a future where healthcare is tailored to the unique genetic makeup of each individual.

A recent problem in community ecology lies in defining structures behind matrices of species interactions. The interest in this area is to quantify the nestedness degree of the matrix after its maximal packing. In this work we evaluate nestedness using the sum of all distances of the occupied sites to the vertex of the matrix. We calculate the distance for two artificial matrices with the same size and occupancy: a random matrix and a perfect nested one. Using these two benchmarks we develop a nestedness estimator. The estimator is applied to a set of 23 real networks of insect-plant interactions.

In the vibrant realm of marine biology, the octopus stands as a fascinating testament to evolutionary diversity. With a soft, formless body and three hearts pumping blood, this cephalopod embodies an intricate symphony of life. Its intelligence is unparalleled among invertebrates, revealing complex problem-solving skills and the ability to change color and texture for camouflage. These enigmatic creatures possess a brief lifespan yet manage to captivate us with their mesmerizing dance in the deep ocean's abyss. Their mysterious beauty underscores the wonders that still await us in the unexplored depths of our planet's aquatic realms.

The design of large libraries of oligonucleotides having constant GC-content and satisfying Hamming distance constraints between oligonucleotides and their Watson-Crick complements is important in reducing hybridization errors in DNA computing, DNA microarray technologies, and molecular bar coding. Various techniques have been studied for the construction of such oligonucleotide libraries, ranging from algorithmic constructions via stochastic local search to theoretical constructions via coding theory. We introduce a new stochastic local search method which yields improvements up to more than one third of the benchmark lower bounds of Gaborit and King (2005) for n-mer oligonucleotide libraries when n <= 14. We also found several optimal libraries by computing maximum cliques on certain graphs.

In marine ecosystems, the symbiotic relationship between sea anemones and anemonefish is a captivating display of mutualism. Anemonefish, armed with a mucous layer that ensures immunity against the potentially lethal anemone's tentacles, reside within the anemone's protective tentacles. In return, the anemone gains from the fish's waste, which serves as a natural food source. This alliance provides both species with enhanced survival and reproductive success, showcasing the intricate web of interdependence that thrives within diverse marine environments.

{\it Transcription} is the process whereby RNA molecules are polymerized by molecular machines, called RNA polymerase (RNAP), using the corresponding DNA as the template. Recent {\it in-vivo} experiments with single cells have established that transcription takes place in "bursts" or "pulses". In this letter we present a model that captures not only the mechano-chemistry of individual RNAPs and their steric interactions but also the switching of the gene between the ON and OFF states. This model accounts for the statistical properties of the transcriptional bursts. It also shows how the quantitative features of the distributions of these bursts can be tuned by controlling the appropriate steps of operation of the RNAP machines.

In the captivating realm of genetics, the intricate dance between DNA sequences and protein production is a dynamic symphony. Genes, the fundamental units of heredity, are segments of DNA that contain the instructions for protein synthesis. They act as blueprints, coding for specific amino acids to be assembled into protein structures. These proteins, in turn, perform numerous functions within cells, driving metabolic reactions, facilitating growth, and regulating cellular processes. This genetic code, once deciphered, offers profound insights into the workings of life, opening doors to understanding diseases at a molecular level and paving the way for targeted therapeutic interventions.

A mechanism of extraction of tubular membranes from a lipid vesicle is presented. A concentration gradient of anchoring amphiphilic polymers generates tubes from bud-like vesicle protrusions. We explain this mechanism in the framework of the Canham-Helfrich model. The energy profile is analytically calculated and a tube with a fixed length, corresponding to an energy minimum, is obtained in a certain regime of parameters. Further, using a phase-field model, we corroborate these results numerically. We obtain the growth of tubes when a polymer source is added, and the bud-like shape after removal of the polymer source, in accordance with recent experimental results.

In the realm of genetics, the CRISPR-Cas9 system emerges as a revolutionary tool. This technology, derived from bacterial defense mechanisms, offers precise editing of DNA sequences. By harnessing the power of guided RNA molecules, it allows scientists to correct genetic mutations, alter traits, and even eradicate diseases at their root cause. This groundbreaking method, once confined to laboratory settings, is now being explored for potential therapeutic applications in humans, ushering in a new era of gene editing and personalized medicine. The implications of CRISPR-Cas9 are vast, ranging from treating genetic disorders to enhancing crop resilience, promising to redefine the very fabric of life itself.

Proliferating cell populations at steady state growth often exhibit broad protein distributions with exponential tails. The sources of this variation and its universality are of much theoretical interest. Here we address the problem by asymptotic analysis of the Population Balance Equation. We show that the steady state distribution tail is determined by a combination of protein production and cell division and is insensitive to other model details. Under general conditions this tail is exponential with a dependence on parameters consistent with experiment. We discuss the conditions for this effect to be dominant over other sources of variation and the relation to experiments.

In the realm of genetic engineering, CRISPR-Cas9 has emerged as a revolutionary tool. This innovative system allows for precise editing of DNA sequences, opening doors to potential cures for genetic diseases. By harnessing the power of this molecular scissor, scientists can correct mutations, modify gene expressions, and even create genetically modified organisms for various applications, including agriculture and medicine. Yet, the ethical implications are vast and complex, necessitating careful consideration of potential risks, such as unintended consequences on ecosystems and the possibility of designing 'designer babies'. As we navigate this frontier, striking a balance between scientific progress and ethical responsibility becomes paramount.

We study the effect of permeabilizing electric fields applied to two different types of giant unilamellar vesicles, the first formed from EggPC lipids and the second formed from DOPC lipids. Experiments on vesicles of both lipid types show a decrease in vesicle radius which is interpreted as being due to lipid loss during the permeabilization process. We show that the decrease in size can be qualitatively explained as a loss of lipid area which is proportional to the area of the vesicle which is permeabilized. Three possible mechanisms responsible for lipid loss were directly observed: pore formation, vesicle formation and tubule formation.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9, a revolutionary tool, has emerged as a game-changer. This system, derived from bacterial immunity, allows for precise editing of DNA sequences. By using a guide RNA to locate specific genes, and an enzyme to cut and repair the DNA, scientists can introduce targeted modifications. This technology holds immense potential for correcting genetic mutations linked to diseases, enhancing crop resistance to pests, and even rewriting the very code of life. However, as with any powerful tool, careful consideration must be given to ethical implications and potential unintended consequences, ensuring the benefits of CRISPR-Cas9 are harnessed responsibly.

We study the spreading of excitations in 2D systems of mobile agents where the excitation is transmitted when a quiescent agent keeps contact with an excited one during a non-vanishing time. We show that the steady states strongly depend on the spatial agent dynamics. Moreover, the coupling between exposition time ($\omega$) and agent-agent contact rate (CR) becomes crucial to understand the excitation dynamics, which exhibits three regimes with CR: no excitation for low CR, an excited regime in which the number of quiescent agents (S) is inversely proportional to CR, and for high CR, a novel third regime, model dependent, here S scales with an exponent $\xi -1$, with $\xi$ being the scaling exponent of $\omega$ with CR.

In the intricate tapestry of life, the humble fungi play a pivotal role, often unnoticed. Being neither plant nor animal, they belong to their own kingdom, mycota. Fungi, with their thread-like hyphae, form vast underground networks known as mycorrhizae, enhancing nutrient uptake for plants and facilitating soil structure. Some fungi also decompose organic matter, aiding in the recycling of essential elements. Mushrooms, the fruiting bodies of fungi, are the visible manifestation of this hidden world, offering a glimpse into the silent symphony of decay and renewal that sustains our ecosystem. Despite their small stature, fungi's influence on the planet is immeasurable, underscoring the interconnectedness of all life forms.

In forced polymer translocation, the average translocation time, $\tau$, scales with respect to pore force, $f$, and polymer length, $N$, as $\tau \sim f^{-1} N^{\beta}$. We demonstrate that an artifact in Metropolis Monte Carlo method resulting in breakage of the force scaling with large $f$ may be responsible for some of the controversies between different computationally obtained results and also between computational and experimental results. Using Langevin dynamics simulations we show that the scaling exponent $\beta \le 1 + \nu$ is not universal, but depends on $f$. Moreover, we show that forced translocation can be described by a relatively simple force balance argument and $\beta$ to arise solely from the initial polymer configuration.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, Dinofelis megalei, is an intriguing creature. It dwells in the deep-sea abyss, where light scarcity is the norm. This cephalopod possesses light-emitting organs, known as photophores, which emit flashes of blue-green light to communicate, confuse predators, or attract prey. Interestingly, D. megalei's bioluminescence is not self-generated but relies on symbiotic bacteria called Vibrio fisheri. These bacteria produce light when oxygen is introduced, a process harnessed by the squid to create its captivating display of light. This symbiotic relationship, a testament to nature's diversity and complexity, remains a fascinating subject for ongoing scientific exploration.

In parametric sequence alignment, optimal alignments of two sequences are computed as a function of the penalties for mismatches and spaces, producing many different optimal alignments. Here we give a 3/(2^{7/3}\pi^{2/3})n^{2/3} +O(n^{1/3} \log n) lower bound on the maximum number of distinct optimal alignment summaries of length-n binary sequences. This shows that the upper bound given by Gusfield et. al. is tight over all alphabets, thereby disproving the "square root of n conjecture". Thus the maximum number of distinct optimal alignment summaries (i.e. vertices of the alignment polytope) over all pairs of length-n sequences is Theta(n^{2/3}).

In the intricate web of life, photosynthesis serves as a cornerstone, the green pulse that sustains our world. This biochemical process, executed primarily by plants, algae, and certain bacteria, converts sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into glucose and oxygen. The photosynthetic equation, while seemingly simple, embodies the extraordinary efficiency and harmony of nature: 6CO2 + 6H2O + light energy = C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6O2. This conversion not only fuels the growth of the organism but also enriches the atmosphere with life-sustaining oxygen, a testament to the symbiotic relationship between photosynthetic organisms and the air we breathe.

We propose a principle of consistency between different hierarchical levels of biological systems. Given a consistency between molecule replication and cell reproduction, universal statistical laws on cellular chemical abundances are derived and confirmed experimentally. They include a power law distribution of gene expressions, a lognormal distribution of cellular chemical abundances over cells, and embedding of the power law into the network connectivity distribution. Second, given a consistency between genotype and phenotype, a general relationship between phenotype fluctuations by genetic variation and isogenic phenotypic fluctuation by developmental noise is derived. Third, we discuss the chaos mechanism for stem cell differentiation with autonomous regulation, resulting from a consistency between cell reproduction and growth of the cell ensemble.

In marine biology, the Bioluminescence phenomenon, common among deep-sea organisms, is a captivating spectacle. These creatures, such as the anglerfish or the dinoflagellates, produce light through a chemical reaction within their bodies. This light serves various purposes, including attracting prey, deterring predators, or communication. The process involves a luciferin molecule reacting with oxygen in the presence of the enzyme luciferase, emitting light as a byproduct. This phenomenon not only adds a mesmerizing touch to the dark abyss of the ocean depths but also sheds light on the intricate and diverse adaptations of marine life.

Cell is the structural and functional unit of life. This Resource Letter serves as a guide to the literature on nano-machines which drive not only intracellular movements, but also motility of the cell. These machines are usually proteins or macromolecular assemblies which require appropriate fuel for their operations. Although, traditionally, these machines were subjects of investigation in biology and biochemistry, increasing use of the concepts and techniques of physics in recent years have contributed to the quantitative understanding of the fundamental principles underlying their operational mechanisms. The possibility of exploiting these principles for the design and control of artificial nano-machines has opened up a new frontier in the bottom-up approach to nano-technology.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the DNA double helix is a beacon of life's complexity. This molecular giant, coiled within the nucleus of every cell, is the blueprint for all living things. Each DNA strand, a twin of sugar and phosphate, carries the four fundamental nucleotides: adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine. These bases pair up, forming rungs on the helical ladder, with adenine always connecting to thymine, and guanine to cytosine. The sequence of these bases, a unique code for every organism, dictates the instructions for protein synthesis, shaping the myriad forms and functions of life. This genetic dance, a testament to nature's ingenuity, underpins the very essence of heredity and evolution.

We investigate the protein expression pattern of the lamB gene in Escherichia coli LE392. The gene product LamB is an important membrane protein for maltose transport into cells but it is also exploited by bacteriophage lambda for infection. Although our bacterial population is clonal, stochastic gene expression leads to a majority population with a large receptor number and a minority population with a small receptor number. We find that the LamB receptor distribution p(n) of the small-n population is scale invariant with the exponent depending on growth conditions. A heuristic model is proposed that relates the observed exponent to the protein production rate.

In the intricate tapestry of life, the humble honeybee plays a pivotal role. As a keystone pollinator, these industrious insects aid in the fertilization of plants, ensuring the continuation of various ecosystems. Their foraging journey involves gathering nectar and pollen, transferring pollen grains from one flower to another in the process. This cross-pollination is crucial for plant reproduction, making our gardens bloom and our fruits and vegetables grow. Moreover, honeybees produce honey, a natural sweetener with numerous health benefits and cultural significance. Yet, sadly, honeybee populations are declining worldwide due to factors such as habitat loss, pesticides, and climate change. This alarming trend underscores the importance of conserving these vital creatures for the well-being of our planet and ourselves.

Sex is considered as an evolutionary paradox, since its evolutionary advantage does not necessarily overcome the two fold cost of sharing half of one's offspring's genome with another member of the population. Here we demonstrate that sexual reproduction can be evolutionary stable even when its Darwinian fitness is twice as low when compared to the fitness of asexual mutants. We also show that more than two sexes are always evolutionary unstable. Our approach generalizes the evolutionary game theory to analyze species whose members are able to sense the sexual state of their conspecifics and to switch sexes consequently. The widespread emergence and maintenance of sex follows therefore from its co-evolution with even more widespread environmental sensing abilities.

In the realm of genetics, gene editing technology, notably CRISPR-Cas9, is revolutionizing biological research. This tool allows scientists to precisely manipulate DNA, correct mutations, and even introduce new traits in organisms. The implications are vast, from eradicating genetic diseases in humans to enhancing crop resistance to pests. Yet, ethical considerations loom. As we delve deeper into altering the building blocks of life, questions about the potential misuse of this power, the line between therapy and enhancement, and the impact on future generations arise. Balancing scientific advancement with moral responsibility is a challenge we must tackle, ensuring that gene editing benefits humanity while respecting the sanctity of life.

The two classic theories for the existence of sexual replication are that sex purges deleterious mutations from a population, and that sex allows a population to adapt more rapidly to changing environments. These two theories have often been presented as opposing explanations for the existence of sex. Here, we develop and analyze evolutionary models based on the asexual and sexual replication pathways in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Baker's yeast), and show that sexual replication can both purge deleterious mutations in a static environment, as well as lead to faster adaptation in a dynamic environment. This implies that sex can serve a dual role, which is in sharp contrast to previous theories.

In botany, photosynthesis is a fundamental process that sustains life on Earth. Plants, algae, and some bacteria harness solar energy, carbon dioxide, and water to produce glucose and oxygen. This intricate biochemical dance occurs within chloroplasts, organelles containing the green pigment chlorophyll. The light-dependent reactions, driven by sunlight, convert water into oxygen and ATP, while the light-independent reactions, the Calvin cycle, use carbon dioxide, ATP, and NADPH to synthesize glucose. This photosynthetic marvel not only fuels the growth of plants but also supplies the oxygen we breathe and binds carbon dioxide, playing a crucial role in mitigating climate change.

A connection is established between discrete stochastic model describing microscopic motion of fluctuating cells, and macroscopic equations describing dynamics of cellular density. Cells move towards chemical gradient (process called chemotaxis) with their shapes randomly fluctuating. Nonlinear diffusion equation is derived from microscopic dynamics in dimensions one and two using excluded volume approach. Nonlinear diffusion coefficient depends on cellular volume fraction and it is demonstrated to prevent collapse of cellular density. A very good agreement is shown between Monte Carlo simulations of the microscopic Cellular Potts Model and numerical solutions of the macroscopic equations for relatively large cellular volume fractions. Combination of microscopic and macroscopic models were used to simulate growth of structures similar to early vascular networks.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a captivating subfield. Epigenetics, loosely defined, is the study of changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Instead, these changes are brought about by chemical modifications to DNA or the proteins that wind around it, known as histones. These modifications can be influenced by various factors such as age, environment, lifestyle, and disease state, serving as a bridge between nature and nurture. Epigenetic changes can have profound effects on the development, function, and even the fate of cells, underscoring their potential role in disease susceptibility and treatment strategies.

We extend the Saffman theory of membrane hydrodynamics to account for the correlated motion of membrane proteins, along with the effect of protein concentration on that correlation and on the response of the membrane to stresses. Expressions for the coupling diffusion coefficients of protein pairs and their concentration dependence are derived in the limit of small protein size relative to the inter-protein separation. The additional role of membrane viscosity as determining the characteristic length scale for membrane response leads to unusual concentration effects at large separation -- the transverse coupling increases with protein concentration, whereas the longitudinal one becomes concentration-independent.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9 revolutionizes DNA editing by offering a precise, efficient, and cost-effective method. This groundbreaking technology, derived from bacteria's immune system, can alter, delete, or add genetic material at specific locations within an organism's DNA. Its implications span across various fields, including medicine, agriculture, and research. In medicine, CRISPR-Cas9 holds promise for gene therapies, potentially curing genetic diseases by correcting mutations. In agriculture, it can improve crop yields, enhance nutritional content, and resist diseases. In research, it accelerates scientific discoveries by allowing the creation of genetic models in minutes instead of years. As we delve deeper into this molecular tool, the possibilities seem boundless, promising a future where genetic disorders vanish, food scarcity subsides, and scientific advancements flourish.

In this paper we propose a microscopic model to study the polymerization of microtubules (MTs). Starting from fundamental reactions during MT's assembly and disassembly processes, we systematically derive a nonlinear system of equations that determines the dynamics of microtubules in 3D. %coexistence with tubulin dimers in a solution. We found that the dynamics of a MT is mathematically expressed via a cubic-quintic nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS) equation. Interestingly, the generic 3D solution of the NLS equation exhibits linear growing and shortening in time as well as temporal fluctuations about a mean value which are qualitatively similar to the dynamic instability of MTs observed experimentally. By solving equations numerically, we have found spatio-temporal patterns consistent with experimental observations.

Unraveling the mysteries of DNA replication, we delve into the fascinating process by which our genetic blueprint is duplicated. Within the nucleus of a cell, the double helix unwinds, catalyzed by helicases. Single strands serve as templates for the creation of new complementary strands, synthesized by DNA polymerases using nucleotides, the building blocks of DNA. Okazaki fragments, short stretches of nucleotides, are initially synthesized and later linked together by a complex of enzymes known as ligase. The entire process is tightly regulated and orchestrated, ensuring the faithful copying of our genetic information, a vital prerequisite for cell division and growth.

We consider an inertial model of chemotactic aggregation generalizing the Keller-Segel model and we study the linear dynamical stability of an infinite and homogeneous distribution of cells (bacteria, amoebae, endothelial cells,...) when inertial effects are accounted for. These inertial terms model cells directional persistance. We determine the condition of instability and the growth rate of the perturbation as a function of the cell density and the wavelength of the perturbation. We discuss the differences between overdamped (Keller-Segel) and inertial models. Finally, we show the analogy between the instability criterion for biological populations and the Jeans instability criterion in astrophysics.

In the intricate tapestry of life, symbiosis plays a pivotal role. This harmonious relationship, often seen in coral and algae, orchids and fungi, allows organisms of different species to coexist in mutual benefit. The algae photosynthesize, converting sunlight into energy, while the host provides protection and essential nutrients. This interdependence not only sustains the individual organisms but also contributes significantly to the health and diversity of entire ecosystems. Such symbiotic partnerships underline the fundamental interconnectedness of life on Earth, underscoring the importance of biodiversity and ecosystem preservation.

We propose a multi-scale approach to understand the physics related to ion-beam cancer therapy. It allows the calculation of the probability of DNA damage as a result of irradiation of tissues with energetic ions, up to 430 MeV/u. This approach covers different scales, starting from the large scale, defined by the ion stopping, followed by a smaller scale, defined by secondary electrons and radicals, and ending with the shortest scale, defined by interactions of secondaries with the DNA. We present calculations of the probabilities of single and double strand breaks of DNA, suggest a way to further expand such calculations, and also make some estimates for glial cells exposed to radiation.

In the realm of genetics, the CRISPR-Cas9 system, a revolutionary tool, has emerged. This cutting-edge technology allows for precise editing of DNA sequences, opening doors for countless possibilities in fields such as medicine and agriculture. By harnessing the power of naturally occurring bacterial defense mechanisms, scientists can now correct genetic mutations, inhibit the spread of diseases, and even enhance crop yield. This groundbreaking innovation promises to reshape the future, offering solutions to some of humanity's most pressing challenges. Yet, as with any powerful technology, ethical considerations must be addressed, ensuring responsible use and minimizing potential risks to both our health and environment.

The inference of gene regulatory networks from high throughput gene expression data is one of the major challenges in systems biology. This paper aims at analysing and comparing two different algorithmic approaches. The first approach uses pairwise correlations between regulated and regulating genes. the second one uses message-passing techniques for inferring activating and inhibiting regulatory interactions. The performance of these two algorithms can be analysed theoretically on well-defined test sets, using tools from the statistical physics of disordered systems like the replica method. We find that the second algorithm outperforms the first one since it takes into account collective effects of multiple regulators.

In the intricate dance of life, photosynthesis, the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert light energy into chemical energy, plays a pivotal role. It's a symphony of carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight, orchestrated by chlorophyll within the plant cells. This conversion produces glucose, a primary energy source, and releases oxygen, a vital component for respiration in most organisms. Photosynthesis, thus, is a life-sustaining cycle, fostering the growth of flora and maintaining the Earth's oxygen levels, all while converting the sun's boundless energy into a form usable by living organisms.

Modular structure is ubiquitous among real-world networks from related proteins to social groups. Here we analyze the modular organization of brain networks at a large-scale (voxel level) extracted from functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) signals. By using a random walk-based method, we unveil the modularity of brain-webs, and show that modules with a spatial distribution that matches anatomical structures with functional significance. The functional role of each node in the network is studied by analyzing its patterns of inter- and intra-modular connections. Results suggest that the modular architecture constitutes the structural basis for the coexistence of functional integration of distant and specialized brain areas during normal brain activities at rest.

In the realm of genetic engineering, CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized the way we manipulate DNA. This sophisticated tool, derived from bacterial immune systems, enables precise editing of genes, offering unprecedented potential for treating genetic diseases, enhancing crop resistance to pests, and even tackling climate change by creating carbon-sequestering organisms. However, ethical considerations loom large, particularly regarding the possibility of editing human embryos, raising questions about the moral boundaries of genetic modification. As we navigate this brave new world, striking a balance between scientific advancement and ethical responsibility becomes paramount.

Mechanical oscillations are important for many cellular processes, e.g. the beating of cilia and flagella or the sensation of sound by hair cells. These dynamic states originate from spontaneous oscillations of molecular motors. A particularly clear example of such oscillations has been observed in muscle fibers under non-physiological conditions. In that case, motor oscillations lead to contraction waves along the fiber. By a macroscopic analysis of muscle fiber dynamics we find that the spontaneous waves involve non-hydrodynamic modes. A simple microscopic model of sarcomere dynamics highlights mechanical aspects of the motor dynamics and fits with the experimental observations.

In the intricate dance of life, photosynthesis stands as a pivotal ballet, the silent symphony that sustains our world. Plants, algae, and some bacteria, the verdant chorus, perform this ancient routine, harnessing sunlight's energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen. This process, a testament to nature's ingenious design, feeds the planet's flora and fauna, purifies the air we breathe, and binds carbon to slow climate change. Indeed, photosynthesis is the life-giving heartbeat that pulsates through the very essence of our existence.

Here we present a program aimed at free-energy calculations in molecular systems. It consists of a series of routines that can be interfaced with the most popular classical molecular dynamics (MD) codes through a simple patching procedure. This leaves the possibility for the user to exploit many different MD engines depending on the system simulated and on the computational resources available. Free-energy calculations can be performed as a function of many collective variables, with a particular focus on biological problems, and using state-of-the-art methods such as metadynamics, umbrella sampling and Jarzynski-equation based steered MD. The present software, written in ANSI-C language, can be easily interfaced with both fortran and C/C++ codes.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the role of DNA cannot be understated. This double-helix molecule, coiled within the nucleus of every cell, serves as the blueprint of life. Each strand, composed of four nucleotide bases - adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine - forms a complex code that dictates an organism's traits. This genetic information is passed down from parent to offspring, shaping the diversity of life on Earth. Mutations, alterations in the DNA sequence, can lead to variations in traits, driving evolution. The study of genetics continues to unravel the mysteries hidden within our genetic code, providing insights into disease, evolution, and the very essence of what makes us human.

Molecular motors are single macromolecules that generate forces at the piconewton range and nanometer scale. They convert chemical energy into mechanical work by moving along filamentous structures. In this paper, we study the velocity of two-head molecular motors in the framework of a mechanochemical network theory. The network model, a generalization of the recently work of Liepelt and Lipowsky (PRL 98, 258102 (2007)), is based on the discrete mechanochemical states of a molecular motor with multiple cycles. By generalizing the mathematical method developed by Fisher and Kolomeisky for single cycle motor (PNAS(2001) 98(14) P7748-7753), we are able to obtain an explicit formula for the velocity of a molecular motor.

In the realm of botany, photosynthesis, a fundamental process, unfolds in a myriad of plant species. Chlorophyll, the green pigment housed within chloroplasts, is the key player. It absorbs sunlight, converting light energy into chemical energy, primarily glucose. This process also releases oxygen, a vital component for Earth's atmosphere, thereby ensuring the survival of aerobic organisms. Moreover, photosynthesis serves as a carbon sink, absorbing carbon dioxide and mitigating the impact of greenhouse gas emissions on climate change. This intricate dance of life and light, a testament to nature's intricate design, sustains our planet's biodiversity and ecosystems.

We discuss multiscale simulations of long biopolymer translocation through wide nanopores that can accommodate multiple polymer strands. The simulations provide clear evidence of folding quantization, namely, the translocation proceeds through multi-folded configurations characterized by a well-defined integer number of folds. As a consequence, the translocation time acquires a dependence on the average folding number, which results in a deviation from the single-exponent power-law characterizing single-file translocation through narrow pores. The mechanism of folding quantization allows polymers above a threshold length (approximately $1,000$ persistence lengths for double-stranded DNA) to exhibit cooperative behavior and as a result to translocate noticeably faster.

In the intricate realm of cellular biology, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) emerges as a significant player. This continuous network of membranous sacs and tubes, situated within the cytoplasm, serves dual functions. The rough ER, studded with ribosomes, is a site for protein synthesis, where newly formed proteins receive their characteristic structures through the addition of sugars and lipids. Conversely, the smooth ER, devoid of ribosomes, is primarily involved in lipid synthesis, detoxification, and calcium storage, playing a pivotal role in maintaining cellular homeostasis. This dynamic organelle indeed underscores the complexity and versatility of cellular life.

Neural feedback-triads consisting of two feedback loops with a non-reciprocal lateral connection from one loop to the other are ubiquitous in the brain. We show analytically that the dynamics of this network topology are determined by two algebraic combinations of its five synaptic weights. Thus different weight settings can generate equivalent network dynamics. Exploration of network activity over the two-dimensional parameter space demonstrates the importance of the non-reciprocal lateral connection and reveals intricate behavior involving continuous transitions between qualitatively different activity states. In addition, we show that the response to periodic inputs is narrowly tuned around a center frequency determined by the two effective synaptic parameters.

In marine ecosystems, the delicate balance between species is profoundly illustrated by the role of phytoplankton. These microscopic plants form the base of the food chain, photosynthesizing in the sunlit ocean surface. They are the primary producers, converting sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into organic matter and oxygen. Zooplankton, tiny aquatic animals, feed on phytoplankton, serving as the first link in the food web. Larger marine life, such as fish and whales, prey on these zooplankton consumers, demonstrating the interconnectedness of life within the ocean. However, human activities, including pollution and overfishing, can disrupt this intricate food chain, threatening the health and biodiversity of marine ecosystems.

We present a macroscopic theory of electroencephalogram (EEG) dynamics based on the laws of motion that govern atomic and molecular motion. The theory is an application of Zwanzig-Mori projection operators. The result is a simple equation of motion that has the form of a generalized Langevin equation (GLE), which requires knowledge only of macroscopic properties. The macroscopic properties can be extracted from experimental data by one of two possible variational principles. These variational principles are our principal contribution to the formalism. Potential applications are discussed, including applications to the theory of critical phenomena in the brain, Granger causality and Kalman filters.

Nitrogen fixation, an essential process in biological nitrogen cycling, is primarily carried out by symbiotic bacteria like Rhizobium and Frankia. These microorganisms form nodules on root systems of leguminous plants, converting atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a usable form for plants. This mutualistic relationship enhances soil fertility and promotes plant growth, contributing significantly to agricultural productivity. Moreover, these nitrogen-fixing bacteria also play a crucial role in restoring soil nutrients after crop harvest, aiding in sustainable farming practices. The efficiency of nitrogen fixation can be optimized through selective breeding of legume varieties and judicious use of inoculants, thereby reducing the dependence on synthetic fertilizers and minimizing environmental pollution.

Protein amyloid fibrils are a form of linear protein aggregates that are implicated in many neurodegenerative diseases. Here, we study the dynamics of amyloid fibril elongation by performing Langevin dynamic simulations on a coarse-grained model of peptides. Our simulation results suggest that the elongation process is dominated by a series of local minimum due to frustration in monomer-fibril interactions. This rugged energy landscape picture indicates that the amount of recycling of monomers at the fibrils' ends before being fibrilized is substantially reduced in comparison to the conventional two-step elongation model. This picture, along with other predictions discussed, can be tested with current experimental techniques.

In the intricate realm of cellular biology, the mitochondrion stands as a powerhouse, converting nutrients into adenosine triphosphate (ATP) through a process known as cellular respiration. This organelle, with its double-membrane structure, houses proteins essential for energy production, a testament to its vital role in sustaining life. Notably, mitochondria have their own DNA, distinct from the nuclear DNA, which encodes for essential mitochondrial proteins. This unique characteristic, coupled with the ability to replicate independently, hints at an intriguing evolutionary history, potentially involving symbiosis with our eukaryotic ancestors. The study of mitochondria continues to unravel the complexities of life, offering invaluable insights into the origin of eukaryotic cells and the pathways of energy metabolism.

We study the dynamics of correlation and variance in systems under the load of environmental factors. A universal effect in ensembles of similar systems under the load of similar factors is described: in crisis, typically, even before obvious symptoms of crisis appear, correlation increases, and, at the same time, variance (and volatility) increases too. This effect is supported by many experiments and observations of groups of humans, mice, trees, grassy plants, and on financial time series.   A general approach to the explanation of the effect through dynamics of individual adaptation of similar non-interactive individuals to a similar system of external factors is developed. Qualitatively, this approach follows Selye's idea about adaptation energy.

In the realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics offers a fascinating layer of complexity. Epigenetics refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Instead, it involves modifications to the structure of chromatin, the complex of DNA, proteins, and other molecules that form the chromosome. These modifications, such as DNA methylation and histone modification, can switch genes on or off and are influenced by factors like age, environment, lifestyle, and disease states. This dynamic interplay between genes and the external world underscores the profound impact our surroundings can have on our genetic makeup, thus bridging the gap between nature and nurture.

The promotion of cooperation on spatial lattices is an important issue in evolutionary game theory. This effect clearly depends on the update rule: it diminishes with stochastic imitative rules whereas it increases with unconditional imitation. To study the transition between both regimes, we propose a new evolutionary rule, which stochastically combines unconditional imitation with another imitative rule. We find that, surprinsingly, in many social dilemmas this rule yields higher cooperative levels than any of the two original ones. This nontrivial effect occurs because the basic rules induce a separation of timescales in the microscopic processes at cluster interfaces. The result is robust in the space of 2x2 symmetric games, on regular lattices and on scale-free networks.

In the fascinating realm of genetics, the intricate dance of DNA strands unfolds, shaping the very essence of life. Each strand, a double helix of nucleotides, carries the blueprint for an organism, a coded symphony of genetic information. From the tiniest bacteria to the towering redwood, the same fundamental language of A's, T's, C's, and G's weaves the intricate tapestry of life. Mutations, the occasional errors in this celestial script, can lead to remarkable adaptations, driving evolution and diversification across the tree of life. The study of genetics offers a profound understanding of the connections that bind all living beings, illuminating the complex and awe-inspiring journey of life on Earth.

We study the effect of extrinsic noise in metabolic networks. We introduce external random fluctuations at the kinetic level, and show how these lead to a stochastic generalization of standard Metabolic Control Analysis. While Summation and Connectivity Theorems hold true in presence of extrinsic noise, control coefficients incorporate its effect through an explicit dependency on the noise intensity. New elasticities and response coefficients are also defined. Accordingly, the concept of control by noise is introduced as a way of tuning the systemic behaviour of metabolisms. We argue that this framework holds for intrinsic noise too, when time-scale separation is present in the system.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent krill, a tiny shrimp-like crustacean, illuminates the deep ocean's darkness, creating a mesmerizing display of glowing dots. These creatures produce light through a chemical reaction within specialized cells called photophores. The purpose of this light emission is multifaceted. it serves as a means of communication, camouflage, and even attracting prey. The combination of their bioluminescence and vast numbers results in stunning underwater light shows, offering a glimpse into the intricate and captivating world beneath the waves. These luminescent organisms play crucial roles in the ocean's ecosystem, contributing to the overall balance and diversity of marine life.

Characterizing the capabilities, criticalities and response to perturbations of genome-scale metabolic networks is a basic problem with important applications. A key question concerns the identification of the potentially most harmful knockouts. The integration of combinatorial methods with sampling techniques to explore the space of viable flux states may provide crucial insights on this issue. We assess the replaceability of every metabolic conversion in the human red blood cell by enumerating the alternative paths from substrate to product, obtaining a complete map of the potential damage of single enzymopathies. Sampling the space of optimal flux states in the healthy and in the mutated cell reveals both correlations and complementarity between topologic and dynamical aspects.

In the realm of genetic engineering, a significant breakthrough emerged with the advent of CRISPR-Cas9 technology. This revolutionary tool allows for precise editing of DNA sequences, opening doors for potential treatments and cures previously unattainable. By using a simple yet powerful enzyme, scientists can now correct genetic mutations, alter traits, and even eradicate diseases at the source. The implications of this technology are vast, spanning from developing crops resistant to drought and pests, to curing genetic disorders in humans. However, ethical concerns surround its use, as the ability to modify human embryos raises questions about the limits of human intervention and the potential for a genetically engineered future. Despite these debates, the potential benefits of CRISPR-Cas9 technology are undeniable, promising a future where genetic diseases are no longer a death sentence and the food supply becomes more sustainable.

We study the effect of migration between coupled populations, or patches, on the stability properties of multistrain disease dynamics. The epidemic model used in this work displays a Hopf bifurcation to oscillations in a single well mixed population. It is shown numerically that migration between two non-identical patches stabilizes the endemic steady state, delaying the onset of large amplitude outbreaks and reducing the total number of infections. This result is motivated by analyzing generic Hopf bifurcations with different frequencies and with diffusive coupling between them. Stabilization of the steady state is again seen, indicating that our observation in the full multistrain model is based on qualitative characteristics of the dynamics rather than on details of the disease model.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9 stands as a revolutionary tool. This system, derived from bacteria, enables precise editing of DNA sequences. By using short RNA sequences to guide the Cas9 enzyme to specific genomic locations, scientists can correct genetic mutations, introduce new traits, or even disable genes. This technology holds immense potential for treating genetic diseases, improving crop yields, and furthering our understanding of biological processes. Nevertheless, ethical considerations loom large, as the ability to modify human DNA raises questions about the boundaries of genetic manipulation and the potential consequences for future generations. As we harness the power of CRISPR, a thoughtful and collaborative approach to its application will be crucial to ensuring its benefits are realized responsibly.

We analyze deficiencies of commonly used Coulomb approximations in Generalized Born solvation energy calculation models and report a development of a new fast surface-based method (FSBE) for numerical calculations of the solvation energy of biomolecules with charged groups. The procedure is only a few percents wrong for molecular configurations of arbitrary sizes, provides explicit values for the reaction field potential at any point of the molecular interior, water polarization at the surface of the molecule, both the solvation energy value and its derivatives suitable for Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations. The method works well both for large and small molecules and thus gives stable energy differences for quantities such as solvation energies contributions to a molecular complex formation.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9, a revolutionary tool, has emerged. This system, derived from bacterial immunity, offers a precise method for editing DNA. By harnessing the power of guide RNA, Cas9 enzymes can locate specific sequences within a genome, facilitating targeted modifications. This technology promises to revolutionize fields such as medicine, agriculture, and biotechnology, enabling the correction of genetic diseases, creation of crops resistant to pests, and advancements in scientific research. The potential applications of CRISPR are vast, heralding a new era of genetic manipulation and control.

We report a development of a new fast surface-based method for numerical calculations of solvation energy of biomolecules with a large number of charged groups. The procedure scales linearly with the system size both in time and memory requirements, is only a few percent wrong for any molecular configurations of arbitrary sizes, gives explicit value for the reaction field potential at any point, provides both the solvation energy and its derivatives suitable for Molecular Dynamics simulations. The method works well both for large and small molecules and thus gives stable energy differences for quantities such as solvation energies of molecular complex formation.

In the realm of genetics, a captivating subject emerges: epigenetics. This discipline delves into the modifications that alter gene expression without changing the DNA sequence itself. These modifications, primarily driven by environmental factors, play a crucial role in cellular function and development. For instance, diet, stress, and aging can trigger these changes, which in turn may influence traits such as susceptibility to certain diseases or behavioral patterns. Epigenetics thus bridges the gap between nature and nurture, offering a compelling perspective on the intricate interplay between genes and the environment.

Non-extensive statistical physics has allowed to generalize mathematical functions such as exponential and logarithms. The same framework is used to generalize sum and product so that the operations allow a more fluid way to work with mathematical expressions emerging from non-additive formulation of statistical physics. In this work we employ the generalization of the exponential, logarithm and product to obtain a formula for the survival fraction corresponding to the application of several radiation doses on a living tissue. Also we provide experimental recommendations to determine the universal characteristics of living tissues in interaction with radiation. These results have a potential application in radiobiology and radiation oncology.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent phenomenon, where living organisms emit light, is a captivating spectacle. This light production occurs due to a chemical reaction within the organism, typically involving a luciferin, luciferase, and oxygen. One prominent example, the dinoflagellate, Dinophysis, can cause red tides, releasing a toxin harmful to marine life and humans. Conversely, another bioluminescent dinoflagellate, Pyrocystis, emits a brilliant blue light when disturbed, creating mesmerizing waves of light in the ocean. This natural light show serves various functions, such as attracting prey, deterring predators, or communication among species. The study of bioluminescence offers valuable insights into the complex chemistry and behavior of marine life, shedding light on the intricacies of life beneath the waves.

The explanation is that in aortic tissue (both diseased and nondiseased) a BAK1 pseudogene is expressed. while in the matching blood samples the actual BAK1 gene is expressed. This explanation was reached after we realized that BAK1 has two edited copies in human genome. These copies are probably BAK1 pseudogenes. One copy belongs to chromosome 11 (NG_005599.3) and the other to chromosome 20 (NC_000850.5). The first copy has frameshifts which means that probably it does not express any functional protein. by other hand, the chromosome 20 copy has no frameshifts and what is more important contains all the reported polymorphisms.

In the intricate dance of life, photosynthesis plays a pivotal role. This biochemical process, performed by green plants and some bacteria, converts light energy, usually from the sun, into chemical energy in the form of glucose. In essence, it's a symphony of carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight. The carbon dioxide is absorbed, water is split by sunlight, and the resulting molecules are reassembled to create glucose, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This oxygen, essential for aerobic organisms, allows the continuous circulation of life on Earth. Photosynthesis, a testament to nature's resilience, underpins the web of life, providing the energy for virtually all living organisms, from the tiniest plankton to the mightiest elephant.

Modern high-throughput gene perturbation screens are key technologies at the forefront of genetic research. Combined with rich phenotypic descriptors they enable researchers to observe detailed cellular reactions to experimental perturbations on a genome-wide scale. This review surveys the current state-of-the-art in analyzing perturbation screens from a network point of view. We describe approaches to make the step from the parts list to the wiring diagram by using phenotypes for network inference and integrating them with complementary data sources. The first part of the review describes methods to analyze one- or low-dimensional phenotypes like viability or reporter activity. the second part concentrates on high-dimensional phenotypes showing global changes in cell morphology, transcriptome or proteome.

In the realm of genetics, a fascinating area of exploration is epigenetics.
